[h1]Análise de Tin Star[/h1]

 [b]Você pode ser o xerife bonzinho, ou o corrupto;[/b]
 O jogo possui sistema de reputação que mede suas ações e qualifica sua honra e notoriedade.

 [b]Você pode ter qualidades como doutor, advogado, religioso e estóico;[/b] 
 Na maioria das vezes sua personalidade define quais suas opções de diálogo.

 [b]O jogo possui habilidades;[/b]
 Você pode passar o jogo atirando com pistolas e rifles, 
 ou persuadindo as pessoas para fazerem isso por você.
 
 [b]Experiencia única cada vez que jogar;[/b]
 Os personagens e a historia reagem as suas escolhas de uma forma impressionante.

[b]Eu recomendo esse jogo para pessoas que:[/b]
-Gostam de ler livros de qualquer tipo.
-Possuem intimidade com a lingua inglesa.
-Não se importam com a falta de gráficos.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
*Escolhas profundamente ramificadas.
*Narrativa e história consistente e bem detalhada.
*Sistema de habilidades.
*Sistema de amizade/inimizade com os personagens.
*Excelente livre arbítrio durante o jogo. 
*Rejogabilidade.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
*Pode ser cansativo depois de muita leitura.
*Somente disponível em inglês.
*Sendo baseado somente em texto, requer um pouco de imaginação.

[h1]Bugs:[/h1]
*As vezes o save não sincroniza com a Nuvem Steam,
 mas isso só afetará quem jogar em mais de um PC.

22518079.review: I must say that Tin Star must be one of the most story-rich, narrative driven games that i've ever had the pleasure of playing in recent years. An all without graphics, or sound! That really says something. To tell the truth, i hadn't played an interactive novels before this one, and from now on, i'm comparing every one that i DO play to Tin Star, why? because of the narrative, that's why. In an interactive novel such as this one, especially without graphics or sound, you have to hold the players attention in some way. If you don't, than you've failed a designing the game. However, Tin Star had me hooked all the way from the begining to the end. The writer, Allen Gies has immense talent for writing, and i commend his work. The style in which he delivers each new situation is always engaging, though sometimes feels a bit forced. And with that, let's get into the very few flaws of the game. First of all, the characters. Now, don't get me wrong, I loved the characters in Tin Star. They were very well writen and had diversity, but, their character buildup is very steriotypical. For instance, you've got the stoic cowboy, the renegade gunslinger, the eccentric prospecter, etc. However, like i said before, the way in which they were written makes up for it. The spelling could use some correction, but that's just more nitpicking than anything. And lastly, the ending. The ending feels really forced, and afterwards, you are presented with a lengthey epilouge that tell you what your character did after the ending, instead of letting you play it yourself. I can understand this for the other characters, but for the protagonist, it doesn't make sense to me. One of the negatives to having a simple, white canvas to write a story on is that your eyes start to get annoyed if you look at it for too long. Tin Star has the same problem. When i'm playing a game, i want to be told an engaging and thrilling story. Not be blinded. People with sensetive eyes will not enjoy the experience. I suggest switching to a more eye-freindly backdrop like dark blue, or something. Unfortunatley, ther's no way to change this yourself. And those are really all the negatives. Most of them are really nit-picky things, but negatives nonetheless. Every game has them. All in all, I really reccomend that you try this game. Especially if you want to be told an engaging story with many branching paths. I will definetly be trying more CYOA games, and Zombie Exodus is next!

Buy. This. Game.

A quick clarification, before I begin.  I have spent many hours playing this game on the mobile version.  I saw that it was available on Steam, and picked it up to support the developer.  That's why my time played for this game is so low.

This is truly an amazing game.  It's easily my favorite game I've ever played on a mobile device, and in my top 10 favorite games on any platform.  It has an excellent story, a fully developed world to explore, interesting characters, and very broad flexibility about who you want your Marshal to be and how you want to resolve problems.  It's remarkably wide-open.  You can be a stone-cold killer, an honorable peace maker, a corrupt bastard, someone who just doesn't give a f*ck, or anything else you can come up with.  It's all up to you.  You decide who you want to be.

If you like story, if you like choice, or if you like RPGs, you will love this game.  Tin Star is every bit as good as a AAA BioWare RPG.  Let me say that again:

Tin Star is every bit as good as a AAA BioWare RPG.  Seriously, it's that good.  

Buy this game.  You'll love it.

21416050.review:
[h1]My Thoughts/About The Game[/h1]
Hosted Games did a good job; interactive RPG style novel. Your choices effect how the story goes. Make one bad decision and you must stick with it throughout the story. Most choices don't effect at all, but some are very crucial to the story. Kill that person; bad choice, now everyone thinks you are a terrible person. Now lets get onto the pros and cons.

[b]Pros[/b]
+ 1,376,197 words long/80,000 words each time you play
+ Be male/female and choose your race
+ You can be straight/gay
+ Stats to look at
+ Very well written
+ The game reacts whenever you made a positive/negative decision
+ Realistic (I played as a chinese man and everyone gave me the third degree)

[b]Cons[/b]
- You can't save the game. Only autosaves
- Parts of the story seems out of place
- You already know the names of the people you'll encounter by checking the stats at the beginning
- When doing your own chores, nothing adds to the story

[h1] In Conclusion [/h1]
 Obviously, there are more pros than cons. Tin Star promised me what I would get when I play the game. From beginning to end, I felt like I was always part of the story. I made a bad choice? Now the game makes me feel like shit. Finally, [b]I recommend[/b] this game.

20904481.review:
You don't see very many games set in the Old West, so when one comes along, it's a novelty. 

Tin Star is a Text Adventure, although not in the same sense as Zork, Moonmist, Planetfall, etc. In those games you actually had to type out commands to interact with the world, whereas Tin Star has pre-defined choices. You often get a bunch of options to choose from, but even so, you're still limited to whatever the author programmed. 

In this sense, Tin Star resembles the Choose Your Own Adventure book series, which ran from 1979 to 1998. Anyone who grew up in the 1980s and early 1990s likely spent hours with different CYOA novels. I know I did. 

The story of Tin Star follows a man or a woman (you can select your gender, name, and sexual orientation) who was saved from execution via hanging and made the sheriff of a small town. During the game, you get to meet all sorts of individuals, many of whom can be either friend or foe depending on how you interact with them. 

Unfortunately, I can't delve too much into the story without ruining it, but I can say that there were a number of plot twists. Unlike some AAA titles that advertise "your choices will matter," Tin Star actually makes good on that promise.

There are no graphics, music or sound effects of any kind. This means you'll have to use your imagination to conjure up the imagery, but given that the author provides plenty of information, that's not too difficult. 

One minor benefit to a total lack of audio is that you can easily play your own music in the background without it interrupting anything or being interrupted by the game's music/sound effects.

The system requirements are so low that even a PC that's over a decade old could run Tin Star. So if you have an older machine or an underpowered laptop, rest assured you won't have any problems here.

I do have a few "issues" with the game, however.

1. The visuals consist of black text on an off-white background. While that's a fine setup, it'd be nice if the player could choose their own text and background colors. I know some people prefer using a dark background and lighter text, especially if they're playing in a dimly-lit room. 

2. As far as I can tell, Tin Star only saves your game at the end of each chapter, and only then if you tell it to do so. This is because you can replay the chapter if you want to try something different, which is nice, but it also means you have to start that chapter over at the beginning. 

3. There's only one save file. If you start a new game, your old save will be written over. So if someone else in your household wants to play Tin Star, make sure you back up your save or that they have their own Steam account and use family sharing.

Bottom line: It won't win any awards for being flashy or technologically impressive, but what it does have is a good interactive story with meaningful choices and interesting characters. I'd recommend Tin Star, especially considering it's only $4.99 USD.

20481200.review:
[b]tl;dr -> Once I got my Tin Star, I immediately abused my power and tried to get with every female I encountered. Died to a bear. 11/10 fantastic Western cowboy simulator.[/b]

[b]Cons:[/b]

-addicting, makes you want more

-does not employ the "discovery" system - all main characters' names are revealed in the stats menu

[b]Pros:[/b]

-very well-written story - dynamic characters and lots of interesting scenes

-extensive stats menu - your stats actually impact the story (and your success/failure) significantly

-employs a checkpoint system - many of the choose-your-own-adventure (CYOA) titles do not; reloading a save will subtract from your Legends rating

-employs the Legends system (as seen in the Heroes Rise trilogy) - all of your choices are summarized at the end and give you a rating based on your performance

-easily one of the strongest titles in the CYOA genre (alongside the Heroes Rise trilogy) - the ending has a long summary of what happens due to your decisions

-lots of romance options

-many, many different decisions to make and events to explore

I love choose-your-own-adventure text-based games, and Steam many quality titles, however, Tin Star is very easily one of the strongest available. I started with the Heroes Rise trilogy and have only found a game of equal calibre when I tried Tin Star. I binged through a few other CYOA titles (Champion of the Gods, A Wise Use of Time, Community College Hero: Trial by Fire, and Diabolical), and all of those pale in comparison to Tin Star. I have been saving Choice of Robots for last, and I will be playing that shortly. If you like Westerners and want to roam the deserts of Nevada, then you must try this game out.

ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!

Cheers,

20342640.review:
[b]Played a Chinese lesbian doctor/lawyer/marshal who could shoot lightning from her fingers 10/10 (tin) stars[/b]

This is definitely the best western genre anything (game/movie/book) I have ever experienced- it's exciting, complex (both in plot and regarding the choices you make), and well written. 

first:
-if you love westerns, get this game
-if you tolerate westerns, get this game
-if you hate westerns, avoid this game

-if you like to read or love the CYOA genre, get this game
-if you are not sure if you like the CYOA genre, maybe try a shorter game, like Choice of Robots, before trying this one
-if you hate reading and/or CYOA, why are you here?

Here are some general points
[list]
[*]lots of character customization, from initial choices (iirc you could play as either white, chinese, or native american) to later stat building choices that pop up regularly
[*]lots of side characters to talk to, influence, kill, or romance
[*]split into chapters that each have a smaller plot arc, but follow from previous chapters
[*]very long- one play through took me about 5 hours, and I'm a fairly fast reader. I'm sure subsequent playthroughs will be shorter, but only due to familiarity with the choices available
[*]if you die you can replay the encounter (losing points), go back to the start of the chapter (possibly fewer points are lost? I never took this route), or restart the game. since the game is so long it is good that you are not forced to restart (as in other CYOA games I have played) but it still gives you an incentive to not die ;)
[*]one complaint is that there is a little bit of a dearth of achievements compared to the scale of the game- other choice of games titles (notably Choice of Robots) have many more, and that one is significantly shorter. you also do not start earning achievements until generally the 3/4 pt of the game, as far as I can tell
[*]warning that some of the characters say some racist stuff- if you play as a chinese character be aware that you will be constantly referred to as a 'celestial'. iirc there are some characters who either supported or fought for the confederacy during the civil war. also most white characters have a hatred for the various native american tribes in the area. it's not really a flaw of the game, but a flaw of history/society, and the game handles it much better than many others have. still, if you want to avoid racism, this is might not be the game for you.
[*]in terms of stat building- don't expect any of your stats except for influence to get anywhere close to 100%. maybe if you picked one to totally focus on you could get it pretty high, but I do not thing that that is really an ideal strategy. my highest stat was ~40%. in terms of influence stats, expect at least one of those to go way over 100%! 
[*]some of the mechanics are a little weird, there are many times when you have a certain amount of time/'turns' to use (notably at the beginning of every chapter you can spend time building a stat or persuing other things) but you are not told how many you have, so it can be a little frustrating
[*] the pacing of the game can be a little weird, especially after the climax of the story, but it's not a huge issue and the story is still very enjoyable
[*] at the end of the story you get the chance to read a little epilogue about how all the major and minor characters faired, which was nice
[*]if you don't like gunfights, most (but not all, as far as I can tell) situations can be talked out of. if you don't like talking, you can pretty much just shoot everyone
[/list]

The game actually fulfilled whatever the trailer said.

- It is kind of the biggest interactive novel (So far on steam, that i checked. The 9 hours on my record consist of 3/4 first run, and several other speed run). Prolly the 'ever made' is a sales pitch though. I do know other Visual Novel that's bigger.

17213383.review:
This game is more expansive than you would think.

My experience with interactive novels prior to Tin Star were despicable, to say the least. Now I'm pretty much stalking the company that makes this game.

Tin Star is an interactive novel that can go almost any avenue you can think of. You can name yourself, or choose from a set of names. You can be a man or a woman, and of either gay or straight sexuality. Doctor, lawyer, or I think something else. You can be a good marshal, bad marshal, decent marshal, questionable marshal. it all depends on how you play the game; what sides you take, who you shmooze and who you shoot. 

When I played the demo I ended up as a lawyer, froze to death on my way to my job, retried, then ended up friends with a Mormon cowboy who'd just had a calf shot by a prospector. I shmoozed to the head of the town and angered a woman in a saloon who almost shot a guy for touching her leg (though he was apprently after more). 

Each character has a story, and you can become close to almost all of them. Your influence and persuasion over them can fluctuate depending on your actions and your influence on them decides what happens in the future (they gonna save you from a shot, or loot your body when your dead?). You don't even have to follow through with the whole plotline; you can say f*ck it all  halfway through and just skip town and stop being a marshal. You can go to Mexico. You can be a womanizer, a sharpshooter, a friend of the Native Americans or a target of everyone who sees you. 

Really it's interesting. I will definately play this game through again. The dialoug and otherwise also shifts slightly depending on whether you are a woman marshal or a male marshal; it also shifts, though very slightly, if your relationship is not of the heterosexual sort.

How you act determines whether or not you are remembered. Whether or not you tell people your name or your title as marshal might effect whether or not your deeds have your name stuck on them; the events may be remembered, but will the marshal?

Or you can be a total utter dick and be remembered because you shot at everyone and gave a middle finger to the Natives, the Sheriff, everyone in town and the damn mountains for all you care. F*ck those mountains. They can kiss your ass.

You can stand by and do nothing. You could practically not be there; just sit and watch and let the town fall to ruin or blow itself up, long as you get your coffee and your pay.

Some consequences are unexpected, some are funny, some are fair.

All the writing in this is very good as well. Allen Gies put a good effort into presenting the scenes too you simply but thouroughly. You can get a real feel for the geography around you and the town - Preston Springs - that you reside in. He also did well with characters and the dialouge isn't too bad either (though cheesy in some parts, but not like painful cheesy at all). 

You can also check your stats on your influence and skill in various areas (I reccomend viewing this in both 'graph' and 'story' mode). There's the occasional spelling/grammar mistake, but they aren't noticeable unless you re-read the scene a million times.

Please, please, please get this game. It really is fun and there is an interaction literally every page but a few interleude ones, and there not that long or frequent. I also personally think that you'll find out a bit about yourself if you just go ahead with your own choices, abide by your morals and what you might do. It's pretty interesting. 

Now start your adventure and find out whether your a legend or just a total, unrelenting, feather-dick.

10/10 I'm starting a new game right now.

17082898.review:
I'm not a fan of Westerns all that much. What intrigued me about this title was it's epic length, and that it sounded interesting in that you take on the role of a US Marshall on the Old West frontier. There's not a lot specifically about the story that I can say that will not be full of spoilers, so I will refrain; however, this is one incredibly well-done story, full of far-reaching choices. You can be a dastardly, terribly corrupt lawman, or be a paragon of virtue. The ending Epilogue pretty much shines a light on everything you did during the game, and tells you of the far-reaching consequences as a result.

The only thing I didn't like is the numerous typos ("their" instead of "they're," "peaked" instead of "piqued," and several others); this was especially the case in the latter half of the game. Maybe it's not that big a deal, but if a game is going to be presented in a written medium, it really should be super-tight when it comes to editing and proofreading. Still, a commendable effort if several were caught in the making, as the author thanks numerous people for doing so. I would have loved to have helped proofread this to catch the dozens that I did see while going through it.

Still, none of that is a big deal. I felt an emotional bond to the character, felt some stirrings in the legacy I left behind, and truly enjoyed every moment. I especially liked that it was a long one! Seven hours is quite long for an interactive fiction game, and the author should be commended for his efforts, as well as Choice of Games for publishing this. 

I highly recommend this one, and I hardly ever review games on Steam.

16786443.review:
In Tin Star, you play a US Marshal, presumably occupied with Honor, Law, and Order (there are stats for each category).  My primary complaint about the game is that it offers too much individual freedom, to the point of departing from its premise.  What kind of Marshal blows up dams, robs wagons and shoots people under no provocation?  While many scenarios have diplomatic solutions, violence isn’t only a last resort.  In other words, I think the story might have been more convincing if the player had other careers to choose from, as opposed to being made a Marshal by default.

That being said, any fan of RPG’s should welcome Tin Star.  It’s constructed like a massive Western D&D campaign and is both one of the longest and most interactive titles by Choice of Games.  The challenges it offers are numerous and inventive, avoiding the grindy repetition typical of the RPG genre.

Doskonała gra, którą gorąco polecam wszystkim miłośnikom "interactive novels", RPG czy w ogóle przygody w jakiejkolwiek formie, dla których liczy się treść, a nie forma. "Tin Star" to historia z Dzikiego Zachodu z wszystkimi jego nieodzownymi atrybutami, dająca niespotykaną swobodę graczowi i oferująca na niemal każdym kroku wybory, które często nie są czarno-białe, a ich skutki oczywiste.

"Tin Star" to wspaniała przygoda, która jest w zasadzie interaktywną książką, więc żeby w pełni się nią cieszyć, wymagana jest przynajmniej dobra znajomośc języka angielskiego (bogate słownictwo, literacki styl oraz trochę slangowych wyrażeń) oraz przymknięcia oko na technicznie niedoskonałości. Sposób zapisywania stanu gry nie jest mocną stroną tego tytułu, ale paradoksalnie wychodzi grze na dobre - trzeba uważać, bo każdy wybór ma mniejsze lub większe konsekwencje. W pewnych, wybranych momentach można "cofnąć czas" i zweryfikować swój wybór, ale tracimy wtedy Punkty Legend. Pamiętajmy jednak, że grę można przejść kilka razy, za każdym razem wypróbowywując nowe możliwości i odkrywając inne zakończenia.

Mówiąc o zakończeniach, nie spotkałem dotąd gry z tak rozbudowanym epilogiem. Możemy w nim poznać nie tylko dalsze losy miasteczka i głównych bohaterów, ale i pobocznych postaci, na... wierzchowcu głównego protagonisty kończąc.

Bardzo lubię silnik Choice of games, który mimo ograniczeń pozwala wczuć się w odgrywaną postać, która jest definiowana przez wiele statystyk i parametrów. Nie jest to zwykła tekstówka, czy paragrafówka. Można ją porównać do solowej sesji "papierowego" RPG.

Jeżeli nie wiesz, czy to twoja bajka, polecam wypróbować (za darmo!) gry na stronie Choice of Games: 

https://www.choiceofgames.com/

16429860.review:
Should be noted, as others have pointed out so far, that this is not a game, but more of an interactive novel. 

I'm only a few chapters in, but the writing so far has been top notch. Very descriptive, and captures the imagination on an emboldened tale. The choices given are also pretty interesting. It's not so much as an A or B choice, but a great deal more. Minor spoilers here, about two chapters in, so skip the reminder of this paragraph if you don't want to spoil it. You encounter a cowboy, and a gold panner engaged in a shootout. You first choose how you want to arrive at the scene, and then engage with both characters. You can go in guns blazing, shooting before asking questions, or you can lend an ear to the two men and find out whats really going on. I got a chuckle out of this scene when I had the option to approach the men and, "Tip your hat and say, afternoon gents". You then find out whats going on, and effectively play detective. Listen to both sides of the story, figure out who is in the wrong or right, and then have one of the two pay reperations for what went wrong. Afterwards you can ask one, or both of the men to accompany you on your travels. Both characters are well written, and in the short time I've been with them, I actually feel like I'm friends with them(rather lame I know, but bare with me.)

The game also has a stat system, which is really interesting. Different options you select can have different effects on you. For example, in one section of the story I opted to travel with a ranchhand. He was on the frontier for a while, and offered up a good bit of knowledge on the wilds, and surviving harsh enviroments. As a result, my stats increased for those respective areas. In one section, im given a few days to launder about, and I can practice various things. I can take to target practice, read up on a variety of subjects, go gamble, etc. The stats effect different options, much like mass effect. You can upgrade persuasion, honor, and other traits. It's an interesting concept, and it makes your choice actually feel weighted. 

This game, or novel, is hard to put down, and if you love westerns, and reading in general, you'll greatly enjoy it. Give it ago, it only costs a big mac, beef jerky, case of cheap beer, etc.

16419361.review:
[b]Tin Star 5/5:[/b] Když už není na PCčkách k dispozici nejlepší westernová hra všech dob (ano, samozřejmě narážím na [i]Red Dead Redemption[/i]), tak je na nich alespoň nejlepší westernová „nehra“ v podobě interaktivního románu/„gamebooku“. S tímto svébytným žánrem se to má tak, že jeho kvalita je přímo úměrná dvěma aspektům; jak je to napsané a kolik (a jak) validních možností volby to hráči/čtenáři předkládá. A v obou těchto ohledech nemá [i]Tin Star[/i] konkurenci a to ani zdaleka pouze na poli westernů.

Napsaný je přesně ve stylu těch nejlepších šestákových rodokapsů; tedy stylově i čtivě. Autor umí vystihnou charaktery tak, aby zaujaly již při letmém seznámí a chcete se tak o nich dozvědět více, zvládá mistrně navodit atmosféru (nejen) skrze detaily i gradaci, opakovaně umně navozuje „klid před bouří“ předcházejí vašim rozhodnutím a i jeho akce, dojde-li na ni, má říz. Navíc se vyhýbá laciným klišé (krom těch, které k žánru neodmyslitelně patří). Rozhodně to tedy není uklohněno nějakým rádoby pisálkem. Sám o sobě je to vlastně více než zdařilý žánrový román, který by se ve světě neztratil. Respektive celá série románů, jelikož rozsah je stěží uvěřitelný (cca 1 400 000 slov; jen pro představu celá trilogie Pána prstenů má v originále necelého půl milionu). Tvůrce tvrdí, že narazíte na cca 80 000 slov na jeden průchod hrou. Tolik k hausnumerům.

Čímž se dostáváme k druhému stěžejnímu bodu „gamebooků“. A to sice možnostem volby. Těch tu je bez sebemenší nadsázky nepřeberně. Chcete být dušínovským charakterem bez bázně a hany či naopak dle hesla „silnější pes mrdá“ si podrobíte všechno a všechny? Budete spíše mlčenlivý drsňák, za kterého mluví činy spíše než slova, týpek co pro sklenku ohnivé vody a ránu nejde nikdy daleko či entita skrytá ve stínech , která jedná zásadně přes nátlak „nabídek, které se neodmítají“. Samotář, milovník stejného pohlaví či děvkař? Je to pouze na vás či spíše o vás. Možností voleb je takové množství a mají tak zásadní dopad na vše (od vztahů s postavami přes vaše statistiky i váš domov až po odvíjení dějové linie), že odehrát dvě alespoň rámcově shodné hry snad ani nejde, i kdybyste se o to nakrásně sebevíce snažili. Navíc veškeré akce tu mají bez výjimky odpovídající následky, které chtě nechtě vždy pocítíte; někdy záhy, někdy po několika hodinách. Nikdy to však nesklouzne k tomu, že byste jen tak bez zájmu odklikávali generické možnosti, na kterých ve výsledku houby záleží. Protože záleží a ovlivˇˇnují nejen váš život, ale i životy těch postav, na kterých vám záleží. A to tak že hodně.

Jedinou vadou na kráse jsou snad jen občasná přes koleno lámaně šroubovaná přirovnání a překlepy i gramatické chyby. Není jich sice příliš, ale zase je jich dost na to, abyste si jich všimli. Na druhou stranu s ohledem na rozsah se není co divit. Ovšem nic to nemění na tom, že pokud za život zkusit byť jen jediný interaktivní román (minimálně ke zjištění, zda to je či není váš šálek kávy), tak by jím měl být právě [i]Tin Star[/i]. Jednoduše proto, že je z nich tím vůbec nejlepším.

16346227.review:
Whether or not you should get this game depends on what's more important to you: the trip or the destination. This is one of the two best interactive novels I've ever played (the other being Mecha Ace). the writing is solid, the characters are fun and endearing, and the choices have weight and consequence without feeling shoehorned in just to force you into having to make a weighty decision. Perhaps more importantly, a lot of choices are appropriately grey - it might be honorable to do something, but is it really best (for you or the community)? The only problem has been during a almost every violent encounter I died. There is usually very little hint as to which action is the best one (even if you'd think your character would know better, or could easily perform the feat). Luckily, if you die, you can just restart the encounter. It just costs you "Legend", which I guess is the games rating score. In spite of this, the game is just charming to play. 

So why do I NOT recommend it? Because the ending doesn't make sense. This huge conspiracy is built up over the course of the game, only to lead to a sudden and unexpected confrontation (where you can cordially invite everyone and their parents [literally] as allies, even if you pist them off earlier in yoru adventure) with a learing plot hole. Namely, how does one family threaten the livelihood of America with a small band of outlaws? It's completely nonsensical, and when combined with the rushed ending, becomes disappointing. 

I would only recommend this game if you are willing to enjoy the journey and don't care (much) about the ending. It's the longest interactive novel I've ever played/read... and the most disappointing.

16283173.review:
Bought this on a whim. Wasn't sure what to expect, but was very pleasantly surprised.

What you get is an entirely text based, 10 chapter story where you develop your character as a US Marshal in 19th century Nevada. After some introduction, you start each chapter in the hub of your town where you decide what to spend your limited time and very limited money on, and then something happens that needs a Marshal. The mission of each chapter has a nice variety, ranging from quiet investigations to big skirmishes, and the real selling point here is the choice it gives you on how to approach every thing in them. Generally after some investigating things get drastic and you have to make a series of choices based on your skills, knowledge, and character. With about 4 or 5 and sometimes 8 options for every bit, I never felt too pressured to do one thing or another. The amount of 'just shoot them' options make renegade Shepard look like a pacifist. 

Behind the all text is a very RPG like skill system measuring your abilities, alignment, and relationships. It never explicitly says that you fail or succeed at something due to these values as well as never explicitly says when they're checked like in Fallout, only when they increased. I liked this, it gave some immersion and made me think about what the Marshal could do, rather than what numbers said he could do. I rolled a Lawful Good persuasion gunslinger and when I did those types of things, they worked, but when I tried to build something or wrestling a bear, I was up a creek.

The story gradually built up, with the connections between the chapters being revealed more towards the end. The final ending I got was a little boring, I really just went up to someone, arrested him, and that was it. I probably could have gotten something more interesting if I decided to do more shooting and less talking, and it didn't help there was a weird period of nothing between big action finale and the actual ending of the story. However you do get a full rundown of how your choices made a difference and the ultimate fate of your town and the cast that does give closure.

Mechanistically, the text engine used is bare bones looking, but works fine. Conversations are in a layout that should be recognizable to anyone whose played Mass Effect but much more concise, and the 'asking for information' prompts differentiable from 'threaten and shoot them in the face'. I wish they gave it an interface little flavor though, sometimes it felt like I was just taking a really exciting customer service survey.  Some say there's some poor grammar, but unless your an English major this probably won't bother you alot, I never noticed. If, for example, you were just bothered by 'alot', it might be an issue.

One note: There is permadeath, but only if you 'accept' the fatal mistake. You lose a cosmetic point at the end of the game, but that's it. Additionally, you can save and reload at the end of chapters. Progess is save automatically.

I got 6 hours out of one playthrough, asking every question possible and restarting a chapter a few times to get a better ending. I'd expect another run would be shorter with reading less background, and probably it would take about 4 playthroughs total to see the outcome of most things major. That's quite a bit of game for $5, if you don't mind reading it.



tl;dr: A very intense customer service survey set in 19th century Nevada about making good choices.

16277239.review:
Tin Star is great at setting you up for meaningful choices, and has characters that are easy to engage with. It's very fun and well written, except for the occasional typo or formatting error.

HOWEVER

The game makes the mistake of assuming that you should care about this big trans-continental conspiracy. Which is difficult, as it always seems to be hinted at, and you never really seem to figure out WHAT the conspiracy is. It's meant to be a motivation, but is sloppily executed.

All in all though, I had fun, especially for such a low price.

7.5/10, definitely worth the money

16232869.review:
This game prides itself on having no graphics or sound, only text, so one would imagine that the text would be very well written.
As someone who reads at least one book a week, I feel qualified to judge the quality of writing within a few minutes, and I treated this game as I would treat a book, so 12 minutes in the game was enough for me to know that the writing is mediocre at best.
The premise is also ridiculous. You get some choice in who your character is, but it feels like the game is pushing you to be some sort of doctor-lawyer hybrid. You start the game ready to be hanged for a crime you did or did not commit (it's up to you), and instead of dying you end up in a secret room where someone decides to make you a marshal and set you free to bring law to the land. It was at this point where I had enough and quit the game, going back to Steam to request a refund and write this review

16220371.review:
Choose your own adventure game, i used to have many books like this some fifteen years ago, even though i recently saw them appear on Steam i never bought one. 
This one being set during the Far West period (not sure if you really call this period that name in english?) and the price not being too steep i decided to make the jump.

What a good decision it was, since i picked it up i haven't been able to stop till now to write this review. Story is good, it seems that the decision you make really influence the plot, romance isn't taking too much of the script which is good since i hate when these things takes a too big part in game or films.

If you have a decent english level especially a decent vocabulary and a good reading comprehension you shouldn't have too much trouble to understand everything.

This reminds me of the great serie Deadwood. (watch it if you haven't yet)

Do I recommend this game? Yep, two thumbs up.
